["**Steady State Theory**: This theory, proposed by Fred Hoyle and others in the 1940s, suggests that the universe has always looked the same, with matter constantly being created to replace what's being used up or destroyed.", '**Eternal Inflation Theory**: This idea proposes that our universe is just one small bubble in an endlessly expanding multiverse, where new universes are constantly being created through eternal inflation.', '**Cyclic Model**: This theory suggests that the universe undergoes cycles of expansion and contraction, with each cycle ending in a Big Crunch (the opposite of the Big Bang).', '**Plasma Universe Theory**: This theory proposes that plasma, a high-energy state of matter, is the fundamental substance of the universe, rather than atoms or particles.', '**Quasar-Era Model**: This model suggests that the universe was initially very hot and dense, with quasars (incredibly luminous objects) playing a central role in shaping the cosmos.', "**Mandelbrot's Fractal Universe**: Benoit Mandelbrot proposed a fractal universe where space is self-similar at different scales, challenging the idea of a single Big Bang event.", '**String Theory/M-Theory**: While not directly competing with the Big Bang theory, these theories attempt to unify the fundamental forces and provide an alternative framework for understanding the early universe.']
